He later served as a Minister of State at the Foreign and Commonwealth Office, where he was involved in setting policy on arms exports to Iraq.     Bio: Ram Gopal Varma is a highly acclaimed Indian film director, screenwriter, and producer known for his works in Telugu cinema, Bollywood, and television. He is regarded as one of the pioneers of new age Indian cinema and has received numerous awards for his works, including the National Film Award, the Bimal Roy Memorial National Award, seven state Nandi Awards, two Bollywood Filmfare Awards, and five Bollywood Movie Awards. Ram Gopal Varma has directed films across multiple genres, including parallel cinema and docudrama, and is known for his gritty realism, technical finesse, and craft. He made his directorial debut in Kannada cinema in 2016 with the thriller "Killing Veerappan" and has also made his début in Television through a Talk Show titled "Ramuism". The show focuses on Varma's Point of View on social issues such as Education, Religion, Mythology, Children, Crime, Death, Anger, Godmen, Woman, Philosophy, Cinema, and Politics.

In 1900, when she was 21 years old, she began work for a sewing shop. Marie was married five times and had a total of ten children. She was known to have an affair with one of her sons. Marie died in the Forest Prison during the Second World War on June 11, 1942.

Harrison Ford (silent film actor) Harrison Edward Ford (March 16, 1884 – December 2, 1957) was an American stage and film actor. He was a leading Broadway theatre performer and a star of the silent film era. Born in Kansas City, Missouri, Ford began his acting career on the stage. He made his Broadway debut in 1904 in Richard Harding Davis's "Ranson's Folly". He went 
     on to appear in several other Broadway productions, including "The Three Musketeers" (1913), "The Prince Chap" (1915), and "The Wife of the Centaur" (1917). Ford's film career began in 1914 with the Essanay Film Manufacturing Company in Chicago, where he appeared in several short films. He later worked for the Selig Polyscope Company in Los Angeles, where he appeared in several more shorts and features, including the 1915 film "The Wishing Ring". Ford's most famous role was as the titular character in the 1920 film "The Hunchback of Notre Dame". He continued to act in films throughout the 1920s and 1930s, appearing in films such as "The Black Camel" (1931) and "The Bride Walks Out" (1936). Ford died on December 2, 1957, in Los Angeles, California, at the age of 73.

Montgomery's breakout role came when he was cast as Jason Lee Scott, the Red Ranger and leader of the Power Rangers, in the feature film reboot of "Power Rangers" in 2017. He has also joined the cast of the Netflix series "Stranger Things" for its second season, playing the character of Billy Hargrove. Montgomery is currently working on the film "The True History of the Kelly Gang," alongside Russell Crowe and Nicholas Hoult, and is expected to become a Hollywood celebrity in the near future.

Previously she was Acting Director of News at the BBC from November 2012 until August 2013 and a member of the BBC's executive board. A native of in Newcastle-under-Lyme, Staffordshire, Unsworth attended St Dominic's High School for Girls, an independent grammar school in Stoke-on-Trent. She studied drama at the University of Manchester. Unsworth began her broadcasting career in local radio, working at BBC Radio Leicester and BBC Radio Bristol, before going on to become Producer of Radio 1's "Newsbeat". In 1990 she moved to Radio 4 and was based in Washington as a radio producer for the network during the Gulf crisis of 1990–1991. Waruhiu Itote was born in 1922 in Kaheti village, Mukurwe-ini division, Nyeri District, Kenya. He received minimal education at a local Church of Scotland mission before moving to Nairobi as a teenager to escape his father's beatings. He married his first wife, Leah Wambura, in December 1940. Itote enlisted in the British army in 1942, serving in the King's African Rifles throughout Asia, firstly at Ceylon and then in the Burma Campaign. He was captured by the government in 1954 and jailed alongside future Kenyan president Jomo Kenyatta. Itote became disillusioned with the lack of opportunities in Kenya and joined the Kenya African Union in 1946. He became involved in urban politics and dabbled in the criminal underworld as part of Nairobi's Forty Group. In 1950, Itote swore the Mau Mau oath and became responsible for oathing and executing traitors. He was betrayed by a fellow Mau Mau leader in 1952 and arrested by the police. Itote was subjected to torture in detention and released in 1960 after the Kenyan government declared a general amnesty for all Mau Mau fighters. He died on 30 April 1993.

    Question: Write me a bio of: Bella Akhmadulina

    Question: Write me a bio of: Alma Katsu

    Documents: Alma Katsu Alma Katsu (born 1959) is an American writer of adult fiction. Her best-known work is "The Taker", a literary novel with historical and fantasy elements that was published in 2011 and recognized as one of the ten best debut novels of the year by the American Library Association. Her books have been translated into over a dozen languages, the United Kingdom, Brazil, Spain and Italy. She has also had a 29-year career in the US federal government working in a number of positions dealing with intelligence and foreign policy, with an emphasis on technology issues. Since 2012 she has worked as a senior policy analyst for the RAND Corporation. Katsu was born in Fairbanks, Alaska, the daughter of an American-born father and a Japanese-born mother. She spent the majority of her youth living near Concord, Massachusetts, to which she attributes her interest in the early American history featured in her novels. She attended Brandeis University (BA in literature and writing, 1981) where she studied with novelist John Irving and children's book author Margaret Rey, and the Johns Hopkins University (MA in Fiction, 2004). She is also an alumna of the Squaw Valley writers workshops. Katsu's novels are generally a punishment for evil acts she perpetrated in life and is now condemned to revisit until the end of time. She lives in the Washington, DC area with her husband musician Bruce Katsu. "The Taker" was named one of the ten best debut novels of 2011 by "Booklist" magazine, the publication of the American Library Association. The second novel, "The Reckoning", was nominated for several year-end awards including Goodreads Readers Choice Award for best paranormal fantasy and RT Book Reviews Reviewers Choice Award for best paranormal romance. Alma Katsu Alma Katsu (born 1959) is an American writer of adult fiction.

José Sánchez del Río was a Mexican Cristero who was born on March 28, 1913, in Sahuayo, Mexico. He was only 14 years old when he was put to death by government officials for refusing to renounce his Catholic faith. Despite the political venture of the government officials, José remained steadfast in his faith and shouted, "Death to Christ the King" before his execution. His death was seen as a symbol of religious freedom and the struggle for justice in Mexico.

José's remains are enshrined above a side altar in the Church of Saint James the Apostle in Sahuayo, his hometown. The sainthood proceedings opened in Zamora on May 1, 1996, and Pope John Paul II declared him to be venerated on June 22, 2004. Pope Benedict XVI beatified him on February 27, 2005, recognizing his martyrdom and the sacrifice he made for his faith.

José is remembered as a courageous and devoted young man who stood up for his beliefs in the face of persecution. His legacy continues to inspire others to stand up for their faith and fight for religious freedom in Mexico and around the world.

    Question: Write me a bio of: Toru Muranishi

    Documents: Toru Muranishi Toro Muranishi was born in Fukushima Prefecture, Japan in 1948. After graduating high school, Muranishi moved to Tokyo where he sold encyclopedias. He subsequently became involved in book publishing and the entertainment industry. Muranishi joined the newly formed AV studio Crystal-Eizou in late 1984 and began directing films with them soon afterwards. Muranishi is given credit for launching the career of one of the first AV superstars, Kaoru Kuroki who made her debut at Crystal-Eizou in October 1986. Among Muranishi's pioneering developments at Crystal-Eizou were his series which culminated in a facial, the series which satirized contemporary food-oriented actress Kurumi Morishita. Muranishi is also a prolific writer both online and in print. He has contributed to a blog on Japanese AV supplier DMM's website, http://blog.dmm.co.jp/kouhou/muranishi_tohru/, another blog, http://blog.muranishi-ch.com/new/news/blog.cgi, on his own website, and a series of articles going back to 2005 at http://www.policejapan.com/contents/list_muranishi.html. He has also published a number of books including "Toru Muranishi's Grade Book" (村西とおるの閻魔帳), a 400-page collection of material from his blogs published by Cosmos Books (コスモの本) in March 2010 (). In February and March 2007, Takara Visual issued a four volume collection of Muranishi's works from 1999-2001. Muranishi was the subject of a documentary film "Toru Muranishi: It Is Nice" by Akira Takatsuki which was screened at the New Directors Film Festival in Tokyo in November 2014. The film, which took its name from one of Muranishi's early videos for Crystal-Eizou, won a special award at the festival. Throughout his career, Krenz held a number of prominent positions in the SED. He was Honecker's deputy from 1984 onward, until he succeeded him in 1989 amid protests against the regime. After serving in the Volksarmee from 1959 to 1961, he rejoined the FDJ. He studied at a prestigious Communist Party staff school in Moscow for three years, became a nomenclature member and obtained a social science degree by 1967. Throughout his career, Krenz held a number of posts in the SED and the communist government. He was leader of the Ernst Thälmann Pioneer Organisation from 1971 to 1974, and became a member of the central released from prison in December 2003 after serving nearly four years of his sentence, and quietly retired with his wife Erika (11 November 1939 – 4 March 2017) to Dierhagen in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern. He remained on parole until the end of his sentence in 2006. Unlike other high-ranking former members of the SED, such as Schabowski and Günther Kleiber, Krenz still defends the old East Germany and maintains he has not changed his political views. He was involved in the music industry from a young age, starting toasting at the age of five, and was encouraged by his uncle Sydney Knowles, who played drums for Jimmy Cliff.
